def preprocess_data(self): 
2583    def preprocess_data(self):
2584        """
2585        Preprocess the data: remove NaNs, optionally ensure 'plateID' column is created,
2586        then group by either 'prc', 'plateID', or do no grouping at all if representation == 'object'.
2587        """
2588        # 1) Remove NaNs in both the grouping column and each data column
2589        df = self.df.dropna(subset=[self.grouping_column] + self.data_column)
2590
2591        # 2) Decide how to handle grouping based on 'representation'
2592        if self.representation == 'object':
2593            # -- No grouping at all --
2594            # We do nothing except keep df as-is after removing NaNs
2595            group_cols = None
2596
2597        elif self.representation == 'well':
2598            # Group by ['prc', grouping_column]
2599            group_cols = ['prc', self.grouping_column]
2600
2601        elif self.representation == 'plateID':
2602            # Make sure 'plateID' exists (split from 'prc' if needed)
2603            if 'plateID' not in df.columns:
2604                if 'prc' in df.columns:
2605                    df[['plateID', 'rowID', 'columnID']] = df['prc'].str.split('_', expand=True)
2606                else:
2607                    raise KeyError(
2608                        "Representation is 'plateID', but no 'plateID' column found. "
2609                        "Also cannot split from 'prc' because 'prc' column is missing."
2610                    )
2611            # If the grouping column IS 'plateID', only group by ['plateID'] once
2612            if self.grouping_column == 'plateID':
2613                group_cols = ['plateID']
2614            else:
2615                group_cols = ['plateID', self.grouping_column]
2616
2617        else:
2618            raise ValueError(f"Unknown representation: {self.representation}")
2619
2620        # 3) Perform grouping only if group_cols is set
2621        if group_cols is not None:
2622            df = df.groupby(group_cols)[self.data_column].agg(self.summary_func).reset_index()
2623
2624        # 4) Handle ordering if specified (and if the grouping_column still exists)
2625        if self.order and (self.grouping_column in df.columns):
2626            df[self.grouping_column] = pd.Categorical(
2627                df[self.grouping_column],
2628                categories=self.order,
2629                ordered=True
2630            )
2631        elif (self.grouping_column in df.columns):
2632            # Default to sorting unique values
2633            df[self.grouping_column] = pd.Categorical(
2634                df[self.grouping_column],
2635                categories=sorted(df[self.grouping_column].unique()),
2636                ordered=True
2637            )
2638
2639        return df

Preprocess the data: remove NaNs, optionally ensure 'plateID' column is created, then group by either 'prc', 'plateID', or do no grouping at all if representation == 'object'.

def remove_outliers_from_plot(self): 
2641    def remove_outliers_from_plot(self):
2642        """Remove outliers from the plot but keep them in the data."""
2643        filtered_df = self.df.copy()
2644        unique_groups = filtered_df[self.grouping_column].unique()
2645        for group in unique_groups:
2646            group_data = filtered_df[filtered_df[self.grouping_column] == group][self.data_column]
2647            q1 = group_data.quantile(0.25)
2648            q3 = group_data.quantile(0.75)
2649            iqr = q3 - q1
2650            lower_bound = q1 - 1.5 * iqr
2651            upper_bound = q3 + 1.5 * iqr
2652            filtered_df = filtered_df.drop(filtered_df[(filtered_df[self.grouping_column] == group) & ((filtered_df[self.data_column] < lower_bound) | (filtered_df[self.data_column] > upper_bound))].index)
2653        return filtered_df

Remove outliers from the plot but keep them in the data.

def perform_normality_tests(self): 
2655    def perform_normality_tests(self):
2656        """Perform normality tests for each group and data column."""
2657        unique_groups = self.df[self.grouping_column].unique()
2658        normality_results = []
2659
2660        for column in self.data_column:
2661            for group in unique_groups:
2662                data = self.df.loc[self.df[self.grouping_column] == group, column].dropna()
2663                n_samples = len(data)
2664
2665                if n_samples < 3:
2666                    # Skip test if there aren't enough data points
2667                    print(f"Skipping normality test for group '{group}' on column '{column}' - Not enough data.")
2668                    normality_results.append({
2669                        'Comparison': f'Normality test for {group} on {column}',
2670                        'Test Statistic': None,
2671                        'p-value': None,
2672                        'Test Name': 'Skipped',
2673                        'Column': column,
2674                        'n': n_samples
2675                    })
2676                    continue
2677
2678                # Choose the appropriate normality test based on the sample size
2679                if n_samples >= 8:
2680                    stat, p_value = normaltest(data)
2681                    test_name = "D'Agostino-Pearson test"
2682                else:
2683                    stat, p_value = shapiro(data)
2684                    test_name = "Shapiro-Wilk test"
2685
2686                # Store the result for this group and column
2687                normality_results.append({
2688                    'Comparison': f'Normality test for {group} on {column}',
2689                    'Test Statistic': stat,
2690                    'p-value': p_value,
2691                    'Test Name': test_name,
2692                    'Column': column,
2693                    'n': n_samples
2694                })
2695
2696            # Check if all groups are normally distributed (p > 0.05)
2697            normal_p_values = [result['p-value'] for result in normality_results if result['Column'] == column and result['p-value'] is not None]
2698            is_normal = all(p > 0.05 for p in normal_p_values)
2699
2700        return is_normal, normality_results

Perform normality tests for each group and data column.

def perform_levene_test(self, unique_groups): 
2702    def perform_levene_test(self, unique_groups):
2703        """Perform Levene's test for equal variance."""
2704        grouped_data = [self.df.loc[self.df[self.grouping_column] == group, self.data_column] for group in unique_groups]
2705        stat, p_value = levene(*grouped_data)
2706        return stat, p_value

Perform Levene's test for equal variance.

def perform_statistical_tests(self, unique_groups, is_normal): 
2708    def perform_statistical_tests(self, unique_groups, is_normal):
2709        """Perform statistical tests separately for each data column."""
2710        test_results = []
2711        for column in self.data_column:  # Iterate over each data column
2712            grouped_data = [self.df.loc[self.df[self.grouping_column] == group, column] for group in unique_groups]
2713            if len(unique_groups) == 2:  # For two groups: class_0 vs class_1
2714                if is_normal:
2715                    if self.paired:
2716                        stat, p = pg.ttest(grouped_data[0], grouped_data[1], paired=True).iloc[0][['T', 'p-val']]
2717                        test_name = 'Paired T-test'
2718                    else:
2719                        stat, p = ttest_ind(grouped_data[0], grouped_data[1])
2720                        test_name = 'T-test'
2721                else:
2722                    if self.paired:
2723                        stat, p = pg.wilcoxon(grouped_data[0], grouped_data[1]).iloc[0][['T', 'p-val']]
2724                        test_name = 'Paired Wilcoxon test'
2725                    else:
2726                        stat, p = mannwhitneyu(grouped_data[0], grouped_data[1])
2727                        test_name = 'Mann-Whitney U test'
2728            else:
2729                if is_normal:
2730                    stat, p = f_oneway(*grouped_data)
2731                    test_name = 'One-way ANOVA'
2732                else:
2733                    stat, p = kruskal(*grouped_data)
2734                    test_name = 'Kruskal-Wallis test'
2735
2736            test_results.append({
2737                'Comparison': f'{unique_groups[0]} vs {unique_groups[1]} ({column})',
2738                'Test Statistic': stat,
2739                'p-value': p,
2740                'Test Name': test_name,
2741                'Column': column,
2742                'n_object': len(grouped_data[0]) + len(grouped_data[1]),
2743                'n_well': len(self.df[self.df[self.grouping_column] == unique_groups[0]]) + 
2744                          len(self.df[self.df[self.grouping_column] == unique_groups[1]])})
2745
2746        return test_results

Perform statistical tests separately for each data column.

def perform_posthoc_tests(self, is_normal, unique_groups): 
2748    def perform_posthoc_tests(self, is_normal, unique_groups):
2749        """Perform post-hoc tests for multiple groups based on all_to_all flag."""
2750
2751        from .sp_stats import choose_p_adjust_method
2752
2753        posthoc_results = []
2754        if is_normal and len(unique_groups) > 2 and self.all_to_all:
2755            tukey_result = pairwise_tukeyhsd(self.df[self.data_column], self.df[self.grouping_column], alpha=0.05)
2756            posthoc_results = []
2757            for comparison, p_value in zip(tukey_result._results_table.data[1:], tukey_result.pvalues):
2758                raw_data1 = self.raw_df[self.raw_df[self.grouping_column] == comparison[0]][self.data_column]
2759                raw_data2 = self.raw_df[self.raw_df[self.grouping_column] == comparison[1]][self.data_column]
2760
2761                posthoc_results.append({
2762                    'Comparison': f'{comparison[0]} vs {comparison[1]}',
2763                    'Test Statistic': None,  # Tukey does not provide a test statistic
2764                    'p-value': p_value,
2765                    'Test Name': 'Tukey HSD Post-hoc',
2766                    'n_object': len(raw_data1) + len(raw_data2),
2767                    'n_well': len(self.df[self.df[self.grouping_column] == comparison[0]]) + len(self.df[self.df[self.grouping_column] == comparison[1]])})
2768            return posthoc_results
2769        
2770        elif len(unique_groups) > 2 and self.all_to_all:
2771            print('performing_dunns')
2772
2773            # Prepare data for Dunn's test in long format
2774            long_data = self.df[[self.data_column[0], self.grouping_column]].dropna()
2775
2776            p_adjust_method = choose_p_adjust_method(num_groups=len(long_data[self.grouping_column].unique()),num_data_points=len(long_data) // len(long_data[self.grouping_column].unique()))
2777
2778            # Perform Dunn's test with Bonferroni correction
2779            dunn_result = sp.posthoc_dunn(
2780                long_data, 
2781                val_col=self.data_column[0], 
2782                group_col=self.grouping_column, 
2783                p_adjust=p_adjust_method
2784            )
2785
2786            for group_a, group_b in zip(*np.triu_indices_from(dunn_result, k=1)):
2787                raw_data1 = self.raw_df[self.raw_df[self.grouping_column] == dunn_result.index[group_a]][self.data_column]
2788                raw_data2 = self.raw_df[self.raw_df[self.grouping_column] == dunn_result.columns[group_b]][self.data_column]
2789
2790                posthoc_results.append({
2791                    'Comparison': f"{dunn_result.index[group_a]} vs {dunn_result.columns[group_b]}",
2792                    'Test Statistic': None,  # Dunn's test does not return a specific test statistic
2793                    'p-value': dunn_result.iloc[group_a, group_b],  # Extract the p-value from the matrix
2794                    'Test Name': "Dunn's Post-hoc",
2795                    'p_adjust_method': p_adjust_method,
2796                    'n_object': len(raw_data1) + len(raw_data2),  # Total objects
2797                    'n_well': len(self.df[self.df[self.grouping_column] == dunn_result.index[group_a]]) +
2798                            len(self.df[self.grouping_column] == dunn_result.columns[group_b])})
2799
2800            return posthoc_results
2801
2802        return posthoc_results

Perform post-hoc tests for multiple groups based on all_to_all flag.

def create_plot(self, ax=None): 
2804    def create_plot(self, ax=None):
2805        """Create and display the plot based on the chosen graph type."""
2806
2807        def _generate_tabels(unique_groups):
2808            """Generate row labels and a symbol table for multi-level grouping."""
2809            # Create row labels: Include the grouping column and data columns
2810            row_labels = [self.grouping_column] + self.data_column
2811
2812            # Initialize table data
2813            table_data = []
2814
2815            # Create the grouping row: Alternate each group for every data column
2816            grouping_row = []
2817            for _ in self.data_column:
2818                for group in unique_groups:
2819                    grouping_row.append(group)
2820            table_data.append(grouping_row)  # Add the grouping row to the table
2821
2822            # Create symbol rows for each data column
2823            for column in self.data_column:
2824                column_row = []  # Initialize a row for this column
2825                for data_col in self.data_column:  # Iterate over data columns to align with the structure
2826                    for group in unique_groups:
2827                        # Assign '+' if the column matches, otherwise assign '-'
2828                        if column == data_col:
2829                            column_row.append('+')
2830                        else:
2831                            column_row.append('-')
2832                table_data.append(column_row)  # Add this row to the table
2833
2834            # Transpose the table to align with the plot layout
2835            transposed_table = list(map(list, zip(*table_data)))
2836            return row_labels, transposed_table
2837
2838
2839        def _place_symbols(row_labels, transposed_table, x_positions, ax):
2840            """
2841            Places symbols and row labels aligned under the bars or jitter points on the graph.
2842            
2843            Parameters:
2844            - row_labels: List of row titles to be displayed along the y-axis.
2845            - transposed_table: Data to be placed under each bar/jitter as symbols.
2846            - x_positions: X-axis positions for each group to align the symbols.
2847            - ax: The matplotlib Axes object where the plot is drawn.
2848            """
2849            # Get plot dimensions and adjust for different plot sizes
2850            y_axis_min = ax.get_ylim()[0]  # Minimum y-axis value (usually 0)
2851            symbol_start_y = y_axis_min - 0.05 * (ax.get_ylim()[1] - y_axis_min)  # Adjust a bit below the x-axis
2852
2853            # Calculate spacing for the table rows (adjust as needed)
2854            y_spacing = 0.04  # Adjust this for better spacing between rows
2855
2856            # Determine the leftmost x-position for row labels (align with the y-axis)
2857            label_x_pos = ax.get_xlim()[0] - 0.3  # Adjust offset from the y-axis
2858
2859            # Place row labels vertically aligned with symbols
2860            for row_idx, title in enumerate(row_labels):
2861                y_pos = symbol_start_y - (row_idx * y_spacing)  # Calculate vertical position for each label
2862                ax.text(label_x_pos, y_pos, title, ha='right', va='center', fontsize=12, fontweight='regular')
2863
2864            # Place symbols under each bar or jitter point based on x-positions
2865            for idx, (x_pos, column_data) in enumerate(zip(x_positions, transposed_table)):
2866                for row_idx, text in enumerate(column_data):
2867                    y_pos = symbol_start_y - (row_idx * y_spacing)  # Adjust vertical spacing for symbols
2868                    ax.text(x_pos, y_pos, text, ha='center', va='center', fontsize=12, fontweight='regular')
2869
2870            # Redraw to apply changes
2871            ax.figure.canvas.draw()
2872                    
2873        def _get_positions(self, ax):
2874            if self.graph_type in ['bar','jitter_bar']: 
2875                x_positions = [np.mean(bar.get_paths()[0].vertices[:, 0]) for bar in ax.collections if hasattr(bar, 'get_paths')]
2876
2877            elif self.graph_type == 'violin':
2878                x_positions = [np.mean(violin.get_paths()[0].vertices[:, 0]) for violin in ax.collections if hasattr(violin, 'get_paths')]
2879
2880            elif self.graph_type in ['box', 'jitter_box']:
2881                x_positions = list(set(line.get_xdata().mean() for line in ax.lines if line.get_linestyle() == '-'))                
2882
2883            elif self.graph_type == 'jitter': 
2884                x_positions = [np.mean(collection.get_offsets()[:, 0]) for collection in ax.collections if collection.get_offsets().size > 0]
2885            
2886            elif self.graph_type in ['line', 'line_std']:
2887                x_positions = []
2888            
2889            return x_positions
2890        
2891        def _draw_comparison_lines(ax, x_positions):
2892            """Draw comparison lines and annotate significance based on results_df."""
2893            if self.results_df.empty:
2894                print("No comparisons available to annotate.")
2895                return
2896
2897            y_max = max([bar.get_height() for bar in ax.patches])
2898            ax.set_ylim(0, y_max * 1.3)
2899
2900            for idx, row in self.results_df.iterrows():
2901                group1, group2 = row['Comparison'].split(' vs ')
2902                p_value = row['p-value']
2903
2904                # Determine significance marker
2905                if p_value <= 0.001:
2906                    signiresults_namecance = '***'
2907                elif p_value <= 0.01:
2908                    significance = '**'
2909                elif p_value <= 0.05:
2910                    significance = '*'
2911                else:
2912                    significance = 'ns'
2913
2914                # Find the x positions of the compared groups
2915                x1 = x_positions[unique_groups.tolist().index(group1)]
2916                x2 = x_positions[unique_groups.tolist().index(group2)]
2917
2918                # Stagger lines to avoid overlap
2919                line_y = y_max + (0.1 * y_max) * (idx + 1)
2920
2921                # Draw the comparison line
2922                ax.plot([x1, x1, x2, x2], [line_y - 0.02, line_y, line_y, line_y - 0.02], lw=1.5, c='black')
2923
2924                # Add the significance marker
2925                ax.text((x1 + x2) / 2, line_y, significance, ha='center', va='bottom', fontsize=12)
2926
2927        # Optional: Remove outliers for plotting
2928        if self.remove_outliers:
2929            self.df = self.remove_outliers_from_plot()
2930
2931        self.df_melted = pd.melt(self.df, id_vars=[self.grouping_column], value_vars=self.data_column,var_name='Data Column', value_name='Value')
2932        unique_groups = self.df[self.grouping_column].unique()
2933        is_normal, normality_results = self.perform_normality_tests()
2934        levene_stat, levene_p = self.perform_levene_test(unique_groups)
2935        test_results = self.perform_statistical_tests(unique_groups, is_normal)
2936        posthoc_results = self.perform_posthoc_tests(is_normal, unique_groups)
2937        self.results_df = pd.DataFrame(normality_results + test_results + posthoc_results)
2938
2939        num_groups = len(self.data_column)*len(self.grouping_column)
2940        num_data_columns = len(self.data_column)
2941        self.bar_width = 0.4
2942        spacing_between_groups = self.bar_width/0.5
2943
2944        self.fig_width = (num_groups * self.bar_width) + (spacing_between_groups * num_groups)
2945        self.fig_height = self.fig_width/2
2946        
2947        if  self.graph_type in ['line','line_std']:
2948            self.fig_height, self.fig_width = 10, 10 
2949
2950        if ax is None:
2951            self.fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(self.fig_height, self.fig_width))
2952        else:
2953            self.fig = ax.figure
2954
2955        if len(self.data_column) == 1:
2956            self.hue=self.grouping_column
2957            self.jitter_bar_dodge = False
2958        else:
2959            self.hue='Data Column'
2960            self.jitter_bar_dodge = True
2961        
2962        # Handle the different plot types based on `graph_type`
2963        if self.graph_type == 'bar':
2964            self._create_bar_plot(ax)
2965        elif self.graph_type == 'jitter':
2966            self._create_jitter_plot(ax)
2967        elif self.graph_type == 'box':
2968            self._create_box_plot(ax)
2969        elif self.graph_type == 'violin':
2970            self._create_violin_plot(ax)
2971        elif self.graph_type == 'jitter_box':
2972            self._create_jitter_box_plot(ax)
2973        elif self.graph_type == 'jitter_bar':
2974            self._create_jitter_bar_plot(ax)
2975        elif self.graph_type == 'line':
2976            self._create_line_graph(ax)
2977        elif self.graph_type == 'line_std':
2978            self._create_line_with_std_area(ax)
2979        else:
2980            raise ValueError(f"Unknown graph type: {self.graph_type}") 
2981        
2982        if len(self.data_column) == 1:
2983            num_groups = len(self.df[self.grouping_column].unique())
2984            self._standerdize_figure_format(ax=ax, num_groups=num_groups, graph_type=self.graph_type)
2985
2986        # Set y-axis start
2987        if isinstance(self.y_lim, list):
2988            if len(self.y_lim) == 2:
2989                ax.set_ylim(self.y_lim[0], self.y_lim[1])
2990            elif len(self.y_lim) == 1:
2991                ax.set_ylim(self.y_lim[0], None)
2992
2993        sns.despine(ax=ax, top=True, right=True)
2994        ax.legend(loc='center left', bbox_to_anchor=(1, 0.5), title='Data Column') # Move the legend outside the plot
2995        
2996        if not self.graph_type in ['line','line_std']:
2997            ax.set_xlabel('')
2998
2999        x_positions = _get_positions(self, ax)
3000        
3001        if len(self.data_column) == 1 and not self.graph_type in ['line','line_std']:
3002            ax.legend().remove()
3003            ax.set_xticklabels(ax.get_xticklabels(), rotation=45, ha='right')
3004
3005        elif len(self.data_column) > 1 and not self.graph_type in ['line','line_std']:
3006            ax.set_xticks([])
3007            ax.tick_params(bottom=False)
3008            ax.set_xticklabels([])
3009            legend_ax = self.fig.add_axes([0.1, -0.2, 0.62, 0.2])  # Position the table closer to the graph
3010            legend_ax.set_axis_off()
3011
3012            row_labels, table_data = _generate_tabels(unique_groups)
3013            _place_symbols(row_labels, table_data, x_positions, ax)
3014            
3015        #_draw_comparison_lines(ax, x_positions)    
3016        
3017        if self.save:
3018            self._save_results()
3019
3020        ax.margins(x=0.12)

Create and display the plot based on the chosen graph type.

def get_results(self): 
3366    def get_results(self):
3367        """Return the results dataframe."""
3368        return self.results_df

Return the results dataframe.

def get_figure(self): 
3370    def get_figure(self):
3371        """Return the generated figure."""
3372        return self.fig

Return the generated figure.

def plot_data_from_db(settings): 
3374def plot_data_from_db(settings):
3375    from .io import _read_db, _read_and_merge_data
3376    from .utils import annotate_conditions, save_settings
3377    """
3378    Extracts the specified table from the SQLite database and plots a specified column.
3379
3380    Args:
3381        db_path (str): The path to the SQLite database.
3382        table_names (str): The name of the table to extract.
3383        data_column (str): The column to plot from the table.
3384
3385    Returns:
3386        df (pd.DataFrame): The extracted table as a DataFrame.
3387    """
3388
3389
3390
3391    if isinstance(settings['src'], str):
3392        srcs = [settings['src']]
3393    elif isinstance(settings['src'], list):
3394        srcs = settings['src']
3395    else:
3396        raise ValueError("src must be a string or a list of strings.")
3397    
3398    if isinstance(settings['database'], str):
3399        settings['database'] = [settings['database'] for _ in range(len(srcs))]
3400    
3401    settings['dst'] = os.path.join(srcs[0], 'results')
3402    
3403    save_settings(settings, name=f"{settings['graph_name']}_plot_settings_db", show=True)
3404
3405    dfs = []
3406    for i, src in enumerate(srcs):
3407
3408        db_loc = os.path.join(src, 'measurements', settings['database'][i])
3409        print(f"Database: {db_loc}")
3410        if settings['table_names'] in ['saliency_image_correlations']:
3411            print(f"Database table: {settings['table_names']}")
3412            [df1] = _read_db(db_loc, tables=[settings['table_names']])
3413        else:
3414            df1, _ = _read_and_merge_data(locs=[db_loc],
3415                                    tables = settings['table_names'],
3416                                    verbose=settings['verbose'],
3417                                    nuclei_limit=settings['nuclei_limit'],
3418                                    pathogen_limit=settings['pathogen_limit'])
3419     
3420        dft = annotate_conditions(df1, 
3421                                cells=settings['cell_types'], 
3422                                cell_loc=settings['cell_plate_metadata'], 
3423                                pathogens=settings['pathogen_types'],
3424                                pathogen_loc=settings['pathogen_plate_metadata'],
3425                                treatments=settings['treatments'], 
3426                                treatment_loc=settings['treatment_plate_metadata'])
3427        dfs.append(dft)
3428        
3429    df = pd.concat(dfs, axis=0)
3430    df['prc'] = df['plateID'].astype(str) + '_' + df['rowID'].astype(str) + '_' + df['columnID'].astype(str)
3431    
3432    if settings['cell_plate_metadata'] !=  None:
3433        df = df.dropna(subset='host_cell')
3434
3435    if settings['pathogen_plate_metadata'] !=  None:
3436        df = df.dropna(subset='pathogen')
3437
3438    if settings['treatment_plate_metadata'] !=  None:
3439        df = df.dropna(subset='treatment')
3440
3441    df = df.dropna(subset=settings['data_column'])
3442        
3443    if settings['grouping_column'] not in df.columns:
3444        print(f"Grouping column {settings['grouping_column']} not found in DataFrame.")
3445        print(f'Please use one of the following columns: {df.columns}')
3446        display(df)
3447        return None
3448    
3449    df = df.dropna(subset=settings['grouping_column'])
3450
3451    src = srcs[0] 
3452    dst = os.path.join(src, 'results', settings['graph_name'])
3453    os.makedirs(dst, exist_ok=True)
3454    
3455    spacr_graph = spacrGraph(
3456        df=df,                                       # Your DataFrame
3457        grouping_column=settings['grouping_column'], # Column for grouping the data (x-axis)
3458        data_column=settings['data_column'],         # Column for the data (y-axis)
3459        graph_type=settings['graph_type'],           # Type of plot ('bar', 'box', 'violin', 'jitter')
3460        graph_name=settings['graph_name'],           # Name of the plot
3461        summary_func='mean',                         # Function to summarize data (e.g., 'mean', 'median')
3462        colors=None,                                 # Custom colors for the plot (optional)
3463        output_dir=dst,                              # Directory to save the plot and results
3464        save=settings['save'],                       # Whether to save the plot and results
3465        y_lim=settings['y_lim'],                     # Starting point for y-axis (optional)
3466        error_bar_type='std',                        # Type of error bar ('std' or 'sem')
3467        representation=settings['representation'],
3468        theme=settings['theme'],                     # Seaborn color palette theme (e.g., 'pastel', 'muted')
3469    )
3470
3471    # Create the plot
3472    spacr_graph.create_plot()
3473
3474    # Get the figure object if needed
3475    fig = spacr_graph.get_figure()
3476    plt.show()
3477
3478    # Optional: Get the results DataFrame containing statistical test results
3479    results_df = spacr_graph.get_results()
3480    return fig, results_df
def plot_data_from_csv(settings): 
3482def plot_data_from_csv(settings):
3483    from .io import _read_db, _read_and_merge_data
3484    from .utils import annotate_conditions, save_settings
3485    """
3486    Extracts the specified table from the SQLite database and plots a specified column.
3487
3488    Args:
3489        db_path (str): The path to the SQLite database.
3490        table_names (str): The name of the table to extract.
3491        data_column (str): The column to plot from the table.
3492
3493    Returns:
3494        df (pd.DataFrame): The extracted table as a DataFrame.
3495    """
3496
3497    if isinstance(settings['src'], str):
3498        srcs = [settings['src']]
3499    elif isinstance(settings['src'], list):
3500        srcs = settings['src']
3501    else:
3502        raise ValueError("src must be a string or a list of strings.")
3503    
3504    dfs = []
3505    for i, src in enumerate(srcs):
3506        dft = pd.read_csv(src)
3507        if 'plateID' not in dft.columns:
3508            dft['plateID'] = f"plate{i+1}"
3509            dft['common'] = 'spacr'
3510        dfs.append(dft)
3511
3512    df = pd.concat(dfs, axis=0)
3513    
3514    if 'prc' in df.columns:
3515        # Check if 'plateID', 'rowID', and 'columnID' are all missing from df.columns
3516        if not all(col in df.columns for col in ['plate', 'rowID', 'columnID']):
3517            try:
3518                # Split 'prc' into 'plateID', 'rowID', and 'columnID'
3519                df[['plateID', 'rowID', 'columnID']] = df['prc'].str.split('_', expand=True)
3520            except Exception as e:
3521                print(f"Could not split the prc column: {e}")
3522
3523                
3524    display(df)
3525
3526    df = df.dropna(subset=settings['data_column'])
3527    df = df.dropna(subset=settings['grouping_column'])
3528    src = srcs[0] 
3529    dst = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(src), 'results', settings['graph_name'])
3530    os.makedirs(dst, exist_ok=True)
3531    
3532    spacr_graph = spacrGraph(
3533        df=df,                                       # Your DataFrame
3534        grouping_column=settings['grouping_column'], # Column for grouping the data (x-axis)
3535        data_column=settings['data_column'],         # Column for the data (y-axis)
3536        graph_type=settings['graph_type'],           # Type of plot ('bar', 'box', 'violin', 'jitter')
3537        graph_name=settings['graph_name'],           # Name of the plot
3538        summary_func='mean',                         # Function to summarize data (e.g., 'mean', 'median')
3539        colors=None,                                 # Custom colors for the plot (optional)
3540        output_dir=dst,                              # Directory to save the plot and results
3541        save=settings['save'],                       # Whether to save the plot and results
3542        y_lim=settings['y_lim'],                     # Starting point for y-axis (optional)
3543        log_y=settings['log_y'],                     # Log-transform the y-axis
3544        log_x=settings['log_x'],                     # Log-transform the x-axis
3545        error_bar_type='std',                        # Type of error bar ('std' or 'sem')
3546        representation=settings['representation'],
3547        theme=settings['theme'],                     # Seaborn color palette theme (e.g., 'pastel', 'muted')
3548    )
3549
3550    # Create the plot
3551    spacr_graph.create_plot()
3552
3553    # Get the figure object if needed
3554    fig = spacr_graph.get_figure()
3555    plt.show()
3556
3557    # Optional: Get the results DataFrame containing statistical test results
3558    results_df = spacr_graph.get_results()
3559    return fig, results_df
def plot_region(settings): 
3561def plot_region(settings):
3562
3563    def _sort_paths_by_basename(paths):
3564        return sorted(paths, key=lambda path: os.path.basename(path))
3565    
3566    def save_figure_as_pdf(fig, path):
3567        os.makedirs(os.path.dirname(path), exist_ok=True)  # Create directory if it doesn't exist
3568        fig.savefig(path, format='pdf', dpi=600, bbox_inches='tight')
3569        print(f"Saved {path}")
3570
3571    from .io import _read_db
3572    from .utils import correct_paths
3573    fov_path = os.path.join(settings['src'], 'merged', settings['name'])
3574    name = os.path.splitext(settings['name'])[0]
3575    
3576    db_path = os.path.join(settings['src'], 'measurements', 'measurements.db')
3577    paths_df = _read_db(db_path, tables=['png_list'])[0]
3578    paths_df, _ = correct_paths(df=paths_df, base_path=settings['src'], folder='data')
3579    paths_df = paths_df[paths_df['png_path'].str.contains(name, na=False)]
3580
3581    activation_mode = f"{settings['activation_mode']}_list"
3582    activation_db_path = os.path.join(settings['src'], 'measurements', settings['activation_db'])
3583    activation_paths_df = _read_db(activation_db_path, tables=[activation_mode])[0]
3584    activation_db = os.path.splitext(settings['activation_db'])[0]
3585    base_path=os.path.join(settings['src'], 'datasets',activation_db) 
3586    activation_paths_df, _ = correct_paths(df=activation_paths_df, base_path=base_path, folder=settings['activation_mode'])
3587    activation_paths_df = activation_paths_df[activation_paths_df['png_path'].str.contains(name, na=False)]
3588
3589    png_paths = _sort_paths_by_basename(paths_df['png_path'].tolist())
3590    activation_paths = _sort_paths_by_basename(activation_paths_df['png_path'].tolist())
3591
3592    
3593    if activation_paths:
3594        fig_3 = plot_image_grid(image_paths=activation_paths, percentiles=settings['percentiles'])
3595    else:
3596        fig_3 = None
3597        print(f"Could not find any cropped PNGs")
3598    if png_paths:
3599        fig_2 = plot_image_grid(image_paths=png_paths, percentiles=settings['percentiles'])
3600    else:
3601        fig_2 = None
3602        print(f"Could not find any activation maps")
3603    
3604    print('fov_path', fov_path)
3605    fig_1 = plot_image_mask_overlay(file=fov_path,
3606                                    channels=settings['channels'],
3607                                    cell_channel=settings['cell_channel'],
3608                                    nucleus_channel=settings['nucleus_channel'],
3609                                    pathogen_channel=settings['pathogen_channel'],
3610                                    figuresize=10,
3611                                    percentiles=settings['percentiles'],
3612                                    thickness=3, 
3613                                    save_pdf=True, 
3614                                    mode=settings['mode'],
3615                                    export_tiffs=settings['export_tiffs'])
3616    
3617    dst = os.path.join(settings['src'], 'results', name)
3618    
3619    if not fig_1 == None:
3620        save_figure_as_pdf(fig_1, os.path.join(dst, f"{name}_mask_overlay.pdf"))
3621    if not fig_2 == None:
3622        save_figure_as_pdf(fig_2, os.path.join(dst, f"{name}_png_grid.pdf"))
3623    if not fig_3 == None:
3624        save_figure_as_pdf(fig_3, os.path.join(dst, f"{name}_activation_grid.pdf"))
3625    
3626    return fig_1, fig_2, fig_3
def plot_image_grid(image_paths, percentiles): 
3628def plot_image_grid(image_paths, percentiles):
3629    """
3630    Plots a square grid of images from a list of image paths. 
3631    Unused subplots are filled with black, and padding is minimized.
3632
3633    Parameters:
3634    - image_paths: List of paths to images to be displayed.
3635
3636    Returns:
3637    - fig: The generated matplotlib figure.
3638    """
3639
3640    from PIL import Image
3641    import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
3642    import math
3643
3644    def _normalize_image(image, percentiles=(2, 98)):
3645        """ Normalize the image to the given percentiles for each channel independently, preserving the input type (either PIL.Image or numpy.ndarray)."""
3646        
3647        # Check if the input is a PIL image and convert it to a NumPy array
3648        is_pil_image = isinstance(image, Image.Image)
3649        if is_pil_image:
3650            image = np.array(image)
3651
3652        # If the image is single-channel, normalize directly
3653        if image.ndim == 2:
3654            v_min, v_max = np.percentile(image, percentiles)
3655            normalized_image = np.clip((image - v_min) / (v_max - v_min), 0, 1)
3656        else:
3657            # If multi-channel, normalize each channel independently
3658            normalized_image = np.zeros_like(image, dtype=np.float32)
3659            for c in range(image.shape[-1]):
3660                v_min, v_max = np.percentile(image[..., c], percentiles)
3661                normalized_image[..., c] = np.clip((image[..., c] - v_min) / (v_max - v_min), 0, 1)
3662
3663        # If the input was a PIL image, convert the result back to PIL format
3664        if is_pil_image:
3665            # Ensure the image is converted back to 8-bit range (0-255) for PIL
3666            normalized_image = (normalized_image * 255).astype(np.uint8)
3667            return Image.fromarray(normalized_image)
3668
3669        return normalized_image
3670
3671    N = len(image_paths)
3672    # Calculate the smallest square grid size to fit all images
3673    grid_size = math.ceil(math.sqrt(N))  
3674
3675    # Create the square grid of subplots with a black background
3676    fig, axs = plt.subplots(
3677        grid_size, grid_size, 
3678        figsize=(grid_size * 2, grid_size * 2),
3679        facecolor='black'  # Set figure background to black
3680    )
3681
3682    # Flatten axs in case of a 2D array
3683    axs = axs.flatten()
3684
3685    for i, img_path in enumerate(image_paths):
3686        ax = axs[i]
3687
3688        # Load the image
3689        img = Image.open(img_path)
3690        img = _normalize_image(img, percentiles)
3691
3692        # Display the image
3693        ax.imshow(img)
3694        ax.axis('off')  # Hide axes
3695
3696    # Fill any unused subplots with black
3697    for j in range(i + 1, len(axs)):
3698        axs[j].imshow([[0, 0, 0]], cmap='gray')  # Black square
3699        axs[j].axis('off')  # Hide axes
3700
3701    # Adjust layout to minimize white space
3702    plt.subplots_adjust(wspace=0, hspace=0, left=0, right=1, top=1, bottom=0)
3703
3704    return fig

Plots a square grid of images from a list of image paths. Unused subplots are filled with black, and padding is minimized.

Parameters:

  • image_paths: List of paths to images to be displayed.

Returns:

  • fig: The generated matplotlib figure.
def overlay_masks_on_images( img_folder, normalize=True, resize=True, save=False, plot=False, thickness=2): 
3706def overlay_masks_on_images(img_folder, normalize=True, resize=True, save=False, plot=False, thickness=2):
3707    """
3708    Load images and masks from folders, overlay mask contours on images, and optionally normalize, resize, and save.
3709
3710    Args:
3711        img_folder (str): Path to the folder containing images.
3712        mask_folder (str): Path to the folder containing masks.
3713        normalize (bool): If True, normalize images to the 1st and 99th percentiles.
3714        resize (bool): If True, resize the final overlay to 500x500.
3715        save (bool): If True, save the final overlay in an 'overlay' folder within the image folder.
3716        thickness (int): Thickness of the contour lines.
3717    """
3718
3719    def normalize_image(image):
3720        """Normalize the image to the 1st and 99th percentiles."""
3721        lower, upper = np.percentile(image, [1, 99])
3722        image = np.clip((image - lower) / (upper - lower), 0, 1)
3723        return (image * 255).astype(np.uint8)
3724
3725    
3726    mask_folder = os.path.join(img_folder,'masks')    
3727    overlay_folder = os.path.join(img_folder, "overlay")
3728    if save and not os.path.exists(overlay_folder):
3729        os.makedirs(overlay_folder)
3730
3731    # Get common filenames in both image and mask folders
3732    image_filenames = set(os.listdir(img_folder))
3733    mask_filenames = set(os.listdir(mask_folder))
3734    common_filenames = image_filenames.intersection(mask_filenames)
3735
3736    if not common_filenames:
3737        print("No matching filenames found in both folders.")
3738        return
3739
3740    for filename in common_filenames:
3741        # Load image and mask
3742        img_path = os.path.join(img_folder, filename)
3743        mask_path = os.path.join(mask_folder, filename)
3744
3745        image = tiff.imread(img_path)
3746        mask = tiff.imread(mask_path)
3747
3748        # Normalize the image if requested
3749        if normalize:
3750            image = normalize_image(image)
3751
3752        # Ensure the mask is binary
3753        mask = (mask > 0).astype(np.uint8)
3754
3755        # Resize the mask if it doesn't match the image size
3756        if mask.shape != image.shape[:2]:
3757            mask = cv2.resize(mask, (image.shape[1], image.shape[0]), interpolation=cv2.INTER_NEAREST)
3758
3759        # Generate contours from the mask
3760        contours, _ = cv2.findContours(mask, cv2.RETR_EXTERNAL, cv2.CHAIN_APPROX_SIMPLE)
3761
3762        # Convert to RGB if grayscale
3763        if image.ndim == 2:
3764            image_rgb = cv2.cvtColor(image, cv2.COLOR_GRAY2RGB)
3765        else:
3766            image_rgb = image.copy()
3767            
3768        # Draw contours with alpha blending
3769        overlay = image_rgb.copy()
3770        cv2.drawContours(overlay, contours, -1, (255, 0, 0), thickness)
3771        blended = cv2.addWeighted(overlay, 0.7, image_rgb, 0.3, 0)
3772        
3773        # Resize the final overlay if requested
3774        if resize:
3775            blended = cv2.resize(blended, (1000, 1000), interpolation=cv2.INTER_AREA)
3776
3777        # Save the overlay if requested
3778        if save:
3779            save_path = os.path.join(overlay_folder, filename)
3780            cv2.imwrite(save_path, cv2.cvtColor(blended, cv2.COLOR_RGB2BGR))
3781        
3782        if plot:
3783            # Display the result
3784            plt.figure(figsize=(10, 10))
3785            plt.imshow(blended)
3786            plt.title(f"Overlay: {filename}")
3787            plt.axis('off')
3788            plt.show()

Load images and masks from folders, overlay mask contours on images, and optionally normalize, resize, and save.

Args: img_folder (str): Path to the folder containing images. mask_folder (str): Path to the folder containing masks. normalize (bool): If True, normalize images to the 1st and 99th percentiles. resize (bool): If True, resize the final overlay to 500x500. save (bool): If True, save the final overlay in an 'overlay' folder within the image folder. thickness (int): Thickness of the contour lines.

def graph_importance(settings): 
3790def graph_importance(settings):
3791    
3792    from .settings import set_graph_importance_defaults
3793    from .utils import save_settings
3794    
3795    if not isinstance(settings['csvs'], list):
3796        settings['csvs'] = settings['csvs']
3797    
3798    settings['src'] = os.path.dirname(settings['csvs'][0])
3799    
3800    settings = set_graph_importance_defaults(settings)
3801    save_settings(settings, name='graph_importance')
3802    
3803    dfs = []
3804    for path in settings['csvs']:
3805        dft = pd.read_csv(path)
3806        dfs.append(dft)
3807
3808    df = pd.concat(dfs)
3809    
3810    if not all(col in df.columns for col in (settings['grouping_column'], settings['data_column'])):
3811        print(f"grouping {settings['grouping_column']} and data {settings['data_column']} columns must be in {df.columns.to_list()}")
3812        return
3813    
3814    output_dir = os.path.dirname(settings['csvs'][0])
3815    
3816    spacr_graph = spacrGraph(
3817        df=df,                                     
3818        grouping_column=settings['grouping_column'],
3819        data_column=settings['data_column'],   
3820        graph_type=settings['graph_type'],   
3821        graph_name=settings['grouping_column'],
3822        summary_func='mean',                         
3823        colors=None,                                
3824        output_dir=output_dir,                              
3825        save=settings['save'],                       
3826        y_lim=None,                     
3827        error_bar_type='std',                       
3828        representation='object',
3829        theme='muted',                    
3830    )
3831
3832    # Create the plot
3833    spacr_graph.create_plot()
3834
3835    # Get the figure object if needed
3836    fig = spacr_graph.get_figure()
3837    plt.show()
def plot_proportion_stacked_bars( settings, df, group_column, bin_column, prc_column='prc', level='object', cmap='viridis'): 
3839def plot_proportion_stacked_bars(settings, df, group_column, bin_column, prc_column='prc', level='object', cmap='viridis'):
3840    """
3841    Generate a stacked bar plot for proportions and perform chi-squared and pairwise tests.
3842    
3843    Parameters:
3844    - settings (dict): Analysis settings.
3845    - df (DataFrame): Input data.
3846    - group_column (str): Column indicating the groups.
3847    - bin_column (str): Column indicating the categories.
3848    - prc_column (str): Optional; column for additional stratification.
3849    - level (str): Level of aggregation ('well' or 'object').
3850    
3851    Returns:
3852    - chi2 (float): Chi-squared statistic for the overall test.
3853    - p (float): p-value for the overall chi-squared test.
3854    - dof (int): Degrees of freedom for the overall chi-squared test.
3855    - expected (ndarray): Expected frequencies for the overall chi-squared test.
3856    - raw_counts (DataFrame): Contingency table of observed counts.
3857    - fig (Figure): The generated plot.
3858    - pairwise_results (list): Pairwise test results from `chi_pairwise`.
3859    """
3860    
3861    from .sp_stats import chi_pairwise
3862    
3863    # Calculate contingency table for overall chi-squared test
3864    raw_counts = df.groupby([group_column, bin_column]).size().unstack(fill_value=0)
3865    chi2, p, dof, expected = chi2_contingency(raw_counts)
3866    print(f"Chi-squared test statistic (raw data): {chi2:.4f}")
3867    print(f"p-value (raw data): {p:.4e}")
3868
3869    # Perform pairwise comparisons
3870    pairwise_results = chi_pairwise(raw_counts, verbose=settings.get('verbose', False))
3871
3872    # Plot based on level setting
3873    if level in ['well', 'plateID']:
3874        # Aggregate by well for mean  SD visualization
3875        well_proportions = (
3876            df.groupby([group_column, prc_column, bin_column])
3877            .size()
3878            .groupby(level=[0, 1])
3879            .apply(lambda x: x / x.sum())
3880            .unstack(fill_value=0)
3881        )
3882        mean_proportions = well_proportions.groupby(group_column).mean()
3883        std_proportions = well_proportions.groupby(group_column).std()
3884
3885        ax = mean_proportions.plot(
3886            kind='bar', stacked=True, yerr=std_proportions, capsize=5, colormap=cmap, figsize=(12, 8)
3887        )
3888        plt.title('Proportion of Volume Bins by Group (Mean  SD across wells)')
3889    else:
3890        # Object-level plotting without aggregation
3891        group_counts = df.groupby([group_column, bin_column]).size()
3892        group_totals = group_counts.groupby(level=0).sum()
3893        proportions = group_counts / group_totals
3894        proportion_df = proportions.unstack(fill_value=0)
3895
3896        ax = proportion_df.plot(kind='bar', stacked=True, colormap=cmap, figsize=(12, 8))
3897        plt.title('Proportion of Volume Bins by Group')
3898
3899    plt.xlabel('Group')
3900    plt.ylabel('Proportion')
3901
3902    # Update legend with formatted labels, maintaining correct order
3903    plt.legend(title=f'Classes', bbox_to_anchor=(1.05, 1), loc='upper left')
3904    plt.ylim(0, 1)
3905    fig = plt.gcf()
3906    
3907    results_df = pd.DataFrame({
3908        'chi_squared_stat': [chi2],
3909        'p_value': [p],
3910        'degrees_of_freedom': [dof]
3911    })
3912
3913    return results_df, pairwise_results, fig

Generate a stacked bar plot for proportions and perform chi-squared and pairwise tests.

Parameters:

  • settings (dict): Analysis settings.
  • df (DataFrame): Input data.
  • group_column (str): Column indicating the groups.
  • bin_column (str): Column indicating the categories.
  • prc_column (str): Optional; column for additional stratification.
  • level (str): Level of aggregation ('well' or 'object').

Returns:

  • chi2 (float): Chi-squared statistic for the overall test.
  • p (float): p-value for the overall chi-squared test.
  • dof (int): Degrees of freedom for the overall chi-squared test.
  • expected (ndarray): Expected frequencies for the overall chi-squared test.
  • raw_counts (DataFrame): Contingency table of observed counts.
  • fig (Figure): The generated plot.
  • pairwise_results (list): Pairwise test results from chi_pairwise.
def create_venn_diagram( file1, file2, gene_column='gene', filter_coeff=0.1, save=True, save_path=None): 
3915def create_venn_diagram(file1, file2, gene_column="gene", filter_coeff=0.1, save=True, save_path=None):
3916    """
3917    Reads two CSV files, extracts the `gene` column, and creates a Venn diagram
3918    to show overlapping and non-overlapping genes.
3919
3920    Parameters:
3921        file1 (str): Path to the first CSV file.
3922        file2 (str): Path to the second CSV file.
3923        gene_column (str): Name of the column containing gene data (default: "gene").
3924        filter_coeff (float): Coefficient threshold for filtering genes.
3925        save (bool): Whether to save the plot.
3926        save_path (str): Path to save the Venn diagram figure.
3927
3928    Returns:
3929        dict: Overlapping and non-overlapping genes.
3930    """
3931    # Read CSV files
3932    df1 = pd.read_csv(file1)
3933    df2 = pd.read_csv(file2)
3934
3935    # Filter based on coefficient
3936    if filter_coeff is not None:
3937        df1 = df1[df1['coefficient'] > filter_coeff] if filter_coeff >= 0 else df1[df1['coefficient'] < filter_coeff]
3938        df2 = df2[df2['coefficient'] > filter_coeff] if filter_coeff >= 0 else df2[df2['coefficient'] < filter_coeff]
3939
3940    # Extract gene columns and drop NaN values
3941    genes1 = set(df1[gene_column].dropna())
3942    genes2 = set(df2[gene_column].dropna())
3943
3944    # Calculate overlapping and non-overlapping genes
3945    overlapping_genes = genes1.intersection(genes2)
3946    unique_to_file1 = genes1.difference(genes2)
3947    unique_to_file2 = genes2.difference(genes1)
3948
3949    # Create a Venn diagram
3950    plt.figure(figsize=(8, 6))
3951    venn = venn2([genes1, genes2], ('File 1 Genes', 'File 2 Genes'))
3952    plt.title("Venn Diagram of Overlapping Genes")
3953
3954    # Save or show the figure
3955    if save:
3956        if save_path is None:
3957            raise ValueError("save_path must be provided when save=True.")
3958        plt.savefig(save_path, dpi=300, bbox_inches="tight", format='pdf')
3959        print(f"Venn diagram saved to {save_path}")
3960    else:
3961        plt.show()
3962
3963    # Return the results
3964    return {
3965        "overlap": list(overlapping_genes),
3966        "unique_to_file1": list(unique_to_file1),
3967        "unique_to_file2": list(unique_to_file2)
3968    }

Reads two CSV files, extracts the gene column, and creates a Venn diagram to show overlapping and non-overlapping genes.

Parameters: file1 (str): Path to the first CSV file. file2 (str): Path to the second CSV file. gene_column (str): Name of the column containing gene data (default: "gene"). filter_coeff (float): Coefficient threshold for filtering genes. save (bool): Whether to save the plot. save_path (str): Path to save the Venn diagram figure.

Returns: dict: Overlapping and non-overlapping genes.
